"Oh, hi. How are you holding up?
Because I am a potato."

                                        -Potato battery GLaDOS

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.
very fun. lots of dopamine as long as you keep testing

A very good game with a good story and great humor. The puzzles are the best and they really make you think, I don't think a third part is necessary but if one day it happened I would be happy to play another portal game again

Portal era sobresaliente. Presentaba unas mec√°nicas, mostraba su narrativa y finalizaba su trayecto con una divertida batalla que pon√≠a a prueba lo aprendido.

La segunda entrega de la saga nos habla directamente en la introducci√≥n del juego para decir "¬ørecuerdas portal?" y luego mejorar exponencialmente todo lo que el titulo original hac√≠a de forma notable.

El movimiento es mas fluido, las salas de pruebas obligan a pensar de forma lateral para resolverlas de originalmente y se presentan nuevas mec√°nicas que abren las puertas a nuevos y locos puzzles que resolver.

Pero esta segunda entrega no solo expande sus mec√°nicas, sino que nos presenta un nuevo personaje, que descadenar√° eventos que ir√°n a√±adiendo capas a la historia de aperture science hasta dejar la primera entrega como un peque√±o trozo en esta gran tarta narrativa.

Glados es una patata.

[h1] Game Details [/h1]
[list]
	[*]   [b] Game Name: [/b] Portal 2
	[*]   [b] Game Release: [/b] 2011
	[*]   [b] Genre Tags: [/b] Puzzle, Story Rich, Atmospheric, Platformer, Co-op
	[*]   [b] Estimated Playtime: [/b] 8-10+ Hours
	[*]   [b] Personal Rating: [/b] 9/10
[/list]

[h1] Review [/h1]
[b] Summary - [/b] Portal 2 is the sequel to the award winning and hugely successful Portal developed by Valve Corporation. It features a single-player story set after the events of Portal's story; and a brand-new Co-op game mode, featuring additional test chambers designed specifically for Cooperative play. Portal 2 takes place an indeterminate amount of time, somewhere between 50 and 50,000 years, after the events of Portal, which saw Chell destroying the sentient computer GLaDOS, and landing outside the facility, only to be dragged back inside of Aperture Science where she was ultimately placed in a Relaxation Chamber by Doug Rattman for the indefinite future.

[b] Story - [/b] First I must say Portal 2 has a masterpiece of an intro! The story brought back GLaDOS (which I'm really glad to see come back). You will find many interesting twists through your playthrough and I honestly really enjoyed it. It‚Äôs a big step up from the previous game and a longer story which I'm really thankful for. I felt like the first Portal game was a bit too short so Portal 2 fixes that and makes the story really fun with more dark humor.

[b] Gameplay - [/b] While Portal had some amazing and unique mechanics, Portal 2 ups the craziness even more! Physics plays an even better role in this game and it makes the game even harder when you get into the later stages. The environments are so stunning and a big step up from the previous game. You still have the same tool from the previous game, which is great and Portal 2 doesn‚Äôt add any weird mechanics for you to use and still keeps it simple. The gameplay is still a masterpiece just like the first Portal, but with more puzzles to mess with, so no complaints here. Ever wanted to play Portal with your friend? You are in luck! Portal 2 now has a cooperative mode, and I must say it is absolutely incredible. So easy to set up and download maps from the Steam Workshop. I mean it‚Äôs Valve, they never really mess up, so no surprises. Honestly Portal 2 is just ahead of its time.

[b] Difficulty - [/b] When I reviewed Portal, my biggest issue was the puzzles, and how easy they were (and I'm really bad at puzzles). Luckily Portal 2 fixes all these problems. You will still find some easy ones here and there throughout the campaign, but my goodness some of them made me use my brain meats a little too hard. Some puzzles in my opinion, were really challenging and people who love puzzles will absolutely love this game a ton. User created maps are also really challenging and bring so much replayability to this game.

[h1] Pros: [/h1]
[list]
	[*] Really fun story
	[*] Funny dark humor
	[*] Amazing level design
	[*] Gorgeous graphics for 2011
	[*] Co-op puzzle game
	[*] Really challenging at times
	[*] Amazing mod support
[/list]

[h1] Cons: [/h1]
[list]
	[*] The second half of the story felt slow
	[*] Co-op with randoms can be a hit or miss
[/list]

Ante la duda de haceros con esta segunda parte de la saga puedo comentaros que tras 11 horas de juego y finalizar la campa√±a principal , recomiendo haceros con el si has jugado el anterior titulo y te gusta el genero . 

Tecnicamente la version que yo he jugado esta muy pulida con una resolucion de 4k y un rendimiento alto en la tasa de framerate . 

La historia principal continua con los personajes de la primera parte  y a√±ade uno importante ,   en esta ocasion tambien amplian   su duracion total y  mejora las herramientas y puzzles  ofreciendo asi  mayor variedad de situaciones .
